document.docAuthor: Bená, Daniela De Cassia & Vanin, Sergio Antonio
document.docTitle: Coarazuphium ricardoi Bená & Vanin, 2014, new species
document.masterDocTitle: A new troglobitic species of Coarazuphium Gnaspini, Vanin & Godoy (Coleoptera, Carabidae, Zuphiini) from a cave in Paraná State, Southern Brazil

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A new troglobitic species of Coarazuphium Gnaspini, Vanin & Godoy (Coleoptera, Carabidae, Zuphiini) from a cave in Paraná State, Southern Brazil

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type material
: Holotype , male, labelled
8-9 .IX. 2011
, R. Pinto-da-Rocha col. ( MZSP ). Paratypes ,
1 male
,
2 females
, same data ( MZSP );
1 male
, same data, but
28 .II. 2012
, Herlon Nadolny col. ( MZSP ).

Type locality
: BRAZIL , Paraná, Doutor Ulysses: Gruta do Varzeão,
24 o 37 ' 49 ''S
49 o 29 ' 58 "W
,
808m .

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 1–3.
Coarazuphium ricardoi
new species , male holotype (1) habitus, dorsal view, (2) head lateral view and (3) detail of eye (Figs.2–3).

FIGURE 4.
Coarazuphium ricardoi
new species , male holotype, habitus, dorsal view.

FIGURES 5–11.
Coarazuphium ricardoi
new species 5–7 male holotype. (5) head, pronotum and prothorax, lateral view, (6) prothorax, ventral view, (7) labrum. (8–11) female paratypes, distal segments of abdomen, (8–9) retracted, (10–11) protracted, coxites exposed.

FIGURES 12–13.
Coarazuphium ricardoi
new species , female paratype. (12) habitus, dorsal view, right elytron removed, arrow pointing to reduced hind wing; (13) detail of reduced hind wing.

subSubSection.paragraph: Etymology . The new species is named after Dr. Ricardo Pinto-da-Rocha, who collected most of the type specimens, in recognition of his outstanding efforts to advance knowledge about the cave fauna of Brazil .

Geographic distribution. The "Gruta do Varzeão" (
Figs. 25–26
), registered as cave PR-0216, is the second largest cave of the State of Paraná, and is located at the foot of the “Serra de Paranapiacaba”, about 12 km of downtown Dr. Ulysses, near the riverside of the "Ribeirão Teixeira" (
Sessegolo et al. 2006
). C
oarazuphium ricardoi
is the first species of the genus found in the speleologic province Vale do Ribeira. This is the southernmost record for the neotropical genus
Coarazuphium
.

Biological notes . According to Dr. Ricardo Pinto-da-Rocha (pers. comm.), four adult specimens of
C. ricardoi
were collected in guano of insectivorous bats, about 30 m from a secondary cave entrance to the "Gruta do Varzeão".

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 14–19.
Coarazuphium ricardoi
new species , male holotype. (14) genital segment and aedeagus, left view, (15) genital segment and aedeagus, right view, (16) genital segment, (17) aedeagus left view, (18) aedeagus dorsal view and (19) aedeagus right view. Legend: lf , left paramere; rp , right paramere.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Taxonomic discussion .
Coarazuphium ricardoi
is microphthalmus, as most species of the genus. The only anophthalmous species of Corazuphium described to date is
C. cessaima
. Four microphtalmous species of the genus have the apical margin of elytra sinuate (
C. bezerra
,
C. caatinga
,
C. formoso
and
C. tessai )
and, although similar, cannot be confused with the new species. The remaining three microphthalmus species (
C. pains
,
C. tapiguassu and C. whiteheadi
) have the apical margin of elytra truncate.
Coarazuphium ricardoi
can be distinguished from each one of these three species by the following characters:
C. pains
has the head dorsally with 3 pairs of setae, the maximum elytral width of elytra posteriad to the transverse midline, and has 2 pairs of prosternal setae (
Álvares & Ferreira 2002
) (
C. ricardoi
: head dorsally with 1 pair of setae, the maximum width of elytra near middle, and 1 pair of prosternal setae);
C. tapiguassu
does not have the pair of posterior supraorbital setae and elytra are proportionately longer and slender (Pellegrini & Ferreira 2011 ) (
C. ricardoi
: with one pair of posterior supraorbital setae and elytra proportionately shorter and broader); in
C. whiteheadi
the head has 3 pairs of setae dorsally and the anterior margin of labrum is irregularly convex (
Ball & Shpeley 2013
) (
C. ricardoi
: head dorsally with 1 pair of setae and the anterior margin of labrum is broadly concave).

The male genital segment of
C. ricardoi
is triangular shaped (
Figs. 14–16
), instead of elliptical, as reported for
C. tessai
,
C. bezerra
and
C. cessaima
(
Gnaspini et al. 1998
: 299, 307
Fig. 11
). The shape of the male genital segment has been illustrated only for
C. cessaima
and
C. ricardoi .
The study of this character should be considered in a future revision of the genus.

The four most similar species of
Coarazuphium
are widely allopatric. Two Brazilian species occur in karst regions;
C. ricardoi
is known from a karst cave in the Vale da Ribeira in the State of Paraná, while
C. pains
occurs in karst caves in the Bambuí speleological province, in the State of Minas Gerais (
Álvares & Ferreira 2002
). The third Brazilian species,
C. tapiguassu ,
is known from small canga caves, located in a complex iron outcrop in Curinópolis, State of Pará (
Pellegrini & Ferreira 2011 b
). The fourth species,
C. whiteheadi
, was collected in the remains of a cloud forest, in Oaxaca, southern Mexico (
Ball & Shpeley 2013
).

caption.paragraph: FIGURES 25–26. The "Gruta do Varzeão", registered as cave PR-0216. (25) View of cave opening from inside the cave. (26) Deeper inside the cave.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Ball & Shpeley's key ( 2013 : 34 ) can be modified as follows to include the new species and the recently described
C. caatinga
Pellegrini & Ferreira 2014
:

paragraph.keyLead:

Gnaspini et al . 1998
: 307 , fig. 6 ). Maximum width of elytra near middle. Male genitalia: right paramere (
Gnaspini et al. 1998
: 306 , fig. 10 ) styliform, about as long as left paramere.........
C. cessaima Gnaspini, Vanin & Godoy
